title: 112_s2286
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook Wild and Scenic River Act". Key findings are also included in the Act. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook Study Act of 2005 authorized the study of the Farmington River and Salmon Brook for potential inclusion in the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System due to their significant natural, cultural, and recreational resources. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook Management Plan, June 2011, establishes objectives, standards, and action programs for long-term protection without Federal management of affected lands. The Committee has voted in favor of Wild and Scenic River designation with strong local support from all ten communities abutting the study area. The State of Connecticut General Assembly has endorsed the designation of the Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook as components of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The Rainbow Dam and Reservoir are located outside of the designated river segment, and the operation of the hydroelectric project is deemed compatible with the designation. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook have been designated as part of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System by the State of Connecticut General Assembly. The Rainbow Dam and Reservoir, located outside the designated river segment, are considered compatible with the designation. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook in Connecticut, totaling approximately 62 miles, are designated as recreational rivers under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. The Farmington River segments include a 27.2-mile stretch from Lower Collinsville Dam to Spoonville Dam, and an 8.1-mile stretch from Rainbow Dam to the Connecticut River confluence. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook in Connecticut, totaling approximately 62 miles, are designated as recreational rivers under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. Specific segments of Salmon Brook, including the main stem, West Branch, and East Branch, are designated as recreational rivers ranging from 2.4 to 12.6 miles in length. The Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook in Connecticut, totaling approximately 62 miles, are designated as recreational rivers under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. Specific segments of Salmon Brook, including the main stem, West Branch, and East Branch, are designated as recreational rivers ranging from 2.4 to 12.6 miles in length. SEC. 4. MANAGEMENT. The river segments designated by section 3 will be managed according to the management plan approved by the Secretary. The Secretary will coordinate with the Lower Farmington River and Salmon Brook Wild and Scenic Committee. The Secretary is authorized to enter into cooperative agreements for the protection and enhancement of the designated river segment. The Secretary is authorized to enter into cooperative agreements with the State of Connecticut, specific towns, and local organizations for the designated river segments. These agreements must be consistent with the management plan and may include assistance from the United States. Zoning ordinances in the designated towns will apply to the segments. The designated river segments in towns in Avon, Bloomfield, Burlington, East Granby, Farmington, Granby, Hartland, Simsbury, and Windsor in Connecticut must meet conservation standards under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. Federal acquisition of lands by condemnation is prohibited for these segments, with acquisition limited to donation or with owner consent. The Lower Farmington River must meet conservation standards under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, with acquisition of lands limited to donation or with owner consent. The designation does not affect the licensing or operations of the Rainbow Dam and Reservoir as a hydroelectric facility. The river shall not be administered as part of the National Park System. SEC. 5. Farmington River, Connecticut, designation revision. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended to change the length of the river and its endpoint. SEC. 6. Definitions. Defines "management plan" and "Secretary" for the Act.
